data.title: Amazon Expands Data-Driven Fashion Push
data.text: While apparel sales have been uneven in 2020, as consumers have shown a greater preference for comfy loungewear to haute couture, Amazon's battle to enter and drive the segment has continued apace. At the end of Q3, Amazon was closing in on $30 billion in gross apparel and footwear sales and within range of finally passing long-time market leader Walmart.

data.title: Amazon encourages California warehouse and Whole Foods workers to get weekly Covid tests
data.text: Amazon sent the notice to California employees in response to new emergency workplace regulations enacted by the state.

data.title: Amazon: Trump corruption the only plausible explanation for Microsoft winning $10B Pentagon contract
data.text: In a newly unsealed court filing, Amazon blames an “extraordinary environment of corruption, interference, and retribution” by President Donald Trump and his administration for improperly influencing what the company contends was an otherwise inexplicable decision by the U.

data.title: Amazon urges judge to set aside $10 billion cloud contract award to Microsoft
data.text: Amazon.com urged a U.S. judge to toss out the Pentagon's $10 billion JEDI cloud computing contract award after the Defense Department in September said a court-ordered re-evaluation had determined Microsoft Corp's proposal still represented the best value for the government.

data.title: Great Quarter, Guys: Is custom fashion Amazon's next breakthrough?
data.text: Andrew Cox and Seth Holm let you know the business news they care about during the North American Supply Chain Summit. Coming to you live: You care or nah?

data.title: Amazon alleges that the Pentagon's decision to give the $10 billion JEDI cloud contract to Microsoft is 'the product of an increasingly corrupt environment under the Trump administration' (AMZN, MSFT)
data.text: Amazon Web Services latest complaint in its lawsuit over the Pentagon's decision to award a cloud computing contract worth as much as $10 billion to Microsoft became public Tuesday. In the filing, AWS alleges that political interference played a role in the decision, and that the Pentagon's recent decision to stand by awarding the contract to Microsoft is "the product of an increasingly corrupt environment under the Trump administration."

data.title: AWS introduces new Chaos Engineering as a Service offering
data.text: When large companies like Netflix or Amazon want to test the resilience of their systems, they use chaos engineering tools designed to help them simulate worst-case scenarios and find potential issues before they even happen.

data.title: Tech giants face tougher rules, big fines under EU plan
data.text: Big tech companies face hefty fines in Britain and the European Union if they treat rivals unfairly or fail to protect users on their platforms, in proposed regulations unveiled Tuesday by officials in London and Brussels. The EU outlined its long-awaited sweeping overhaul of digital regulations while the British government released its own plans to.

data.title: Instant View: U.S. tech firms face new EU rules for business practices
data.text: Big U.S. technology firms ranging from Apple to Facebook may have to change their business practices in Europe or face fines of as much as 10% of their annual turnover under new draft EU rules announced on Tuesday.

data.title: FTC orders tech giants to share information on how they handle data
data.text: Yahoo Finance's Alexis Keenan reports on the FTC cracking down on tech giants on how they track and handle data.

data.title: AWS launches CloudShell, a web-based shell for command-line access to AWS
data.text: AWS today launched CloudShell, a new, fully-featured web-based shell environment, based on Amazon Linux 2, for developers who want to be able to use some of their favorite command-line tools — and scripts — right inside the AWS Console. CloudShell, Amazon CTO Werner Vogels explained in his announcement today, is a new browser-based service that […]

data.title: Explainer-Tough EU tech rules: here's the what, why and what comes next
data.text: The European Commission announced draft rules on Tuesday to rein in tech giants such as Alphabet's Google, Facebook, Apple and Amazon, the most significant among a raft of measures taken by regulators worldwide.

data.title: Europe lays out its plan to reboot digital rules and tame tech giants
data.text: European lawmakers have introduced two legislative proposals as part of a major policy reboot to update regional rules for digital business and rein in big tech.

data.title: New EU Rules Could Fine U.S. Tech Giants Billions
data.text: Companies like Apple, Google, Amazon and Facebook may face stiff fines if they engage in anti-competitive behavior or fail to act against illegal content.

data.title: The walls are closing in on Big Tech as global regulators crack down
data.text: The European Commission, the FTC and Ofcom have all announced new plans to regulate the tech giants in the last few days.

data.title: Twitter taps AWS for its latest foray into the public cloud
data.text: Twitter has a lot going on, and it's not always easy to manage that kind of scale on your own. Today, Amazon announced that Twitter has chosen AWS to run its real-time timelines.

data.title: EU Digital Services and Digital Markets Acts: Europe's big tech regulation overhaul begins
data.text: The two pieces of proposed legislation will dictate how the EU regulates Big Tech for years to come.

data.title: EU announces sweeping new rules that could force breakups and hefty fines for Big Tech
data.text: Tech giants could soon face hefty fines and stricter controls over their behavior as part of new wide-sweeping rules in the European Union.

data.title: Europe threatens to break up Big Tech if it doesn't play by new rules
data.text: Officials across Europe on Tuesday unveiled legislation that would give regulators sweeping new powers to take on US tech giants, threatening huge fines and raising the prospect of breakups or bans for repeat offenders.

data.title: Big Fines and Strict Rules Unveiled Against ‘Big Tech' in Europe
data.text: European Union and British authorities released draft laws to halt the spread of harmful content and improve competition.

data.title: Big Tech could face break up and billion-dollar fines under new EU regulation being announced Tuesday
data.text: The executive branch of the European Union is scheduled to release two sweeping legislative proposals on Tuesday that will set the stage for regulating Big Tech in Europe.

data.title: Amazon (AMZN) AWS' Selection by Nationwide Expands Client Base
data.text: Amazon's (AMZN) AWS has been selected by Nationwide as the preferred cloud provider. This further expands Amazon's client base.

data.title: Zoox's CEO Sees Amazon-backed Robotaxi Re-imagining Transport
data.text: Dec.15 -- Zoox, the self-driving startup owned by Amazon.com Inc., has unveiled a fully autonomous electric vehicle with no steering wheel. Zoox CEO Aicha Evans speaks exclusively to Bloomberg's Ed Ludlow about the company's business plan, timeline for deployment and Amazon's backing.

data.title: Amazon Fashion Brings Out Specialty T-Shirts Made To Customers' Measurements
data.text: Amazon Fashion wants customers to have it their way. This time around, the pitch is not on the luxury side — rather, it's about creating a custom T-shirt.

data.title: Amazon launches new service that uses a virtual body double to create custom shirts
data.text: The service, called Made for You, takes a user's measurements and creates a virtual body double to model the custom shirt.

data.title: Amazon Stock: Buy, Sell, or Hold Going Into 2021?
data.text: The e-commerce specialist's stock has gone nowhere since July. Is it time to buy?

data.title: AWS says Twitter will use its cloud services to help scale its timeline
data.text: Amazon.com Inc.'s Amazon Web Services announced Tuesday that Twitter Inc. would be using its cloud services to support its delivery of users' timelines. AWS said that the expansion onto its global cloud infrastructure marks the first time that Twitter is using the public cloud to help scale its service.

data.title: Zoox's boxy self-driving vehicle looks nothing like a traditional car
data.text: Four wheels aside, the Amazon-owned company's autonomous vehicle has no clear front or back—and no drivers' seat. The Amazon-owned mobility company Zoox has revealed its autonomous vehicle—a boxy-looking affair that bears few reference points to the human-operated cars we're accustomed to.

data.title: Twitter Selects AWS as Strategic Provider to Serve Timelines
data.text: SEATTLE--(BUSINESS WIRE)--Today, Amazon Web Services, Inc. (AWS), an Amazon.com, Inc. company (NASDAQ: AMZN), announced that Twitter (NYSE: TWTR) has selected AWS to provide global cloud infrastructure to deliver Twitter timelines. Under the multi-year deal, Twitter will leverage AWS's proven infrastructure and portfolio of services to support delivery of millions of daily Tweets. This expansion onto AWS marks the first time that Twitter is leveraging the public cloud to scale their real-time s

data.title: Amazon Fashion launches a custom clothing service, Made for You
data.text: Amazon today is launching a way for customers to create custom clothing with a new service called Made for You, which lets shoppers create a custom T-shirt to their exact measurements. But unlike some companies that use mobile technology to scan and measure your body from an app, Amazon Fashion's Made for You service requires […]

data.title: Why Pharmacy Sales Could Be Amazon's Prescription for Huge Growth
data.text: The online giant has a three-pronged plan to disrupt drugstores.

data.title: Can Amazon's Stock Pull Off A Repeat Performance In The Next Decade?
data.text: Here are advantages Amazon will carry into 2021 that growth investors should take note of.

data.title: 3 Top Artificial Intelligence Stocks to Buy Right Now
data.text: AI is a huge market and these companies are already benefiting from it.

data.title: EU Threatens Big Tech Breakup Over Anti-Competitive Practices
data.text: As Brussels published its tech legislation drafts, the European Union (EU) warned that it would break up Big Tech for repeated practices that are deemed anti-competitive, the Financial Times (FT) reported on Tuesday (Dec. 15).

data.title: U.S. tech giants face 6-10% fines as EU set rules to curb their power
data.text: Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Alphabet unit Google may have to change their business practices in Europe or face hefty fines between 6-10% under new draft EU rules to be announced on Tuesday.
